description: Every technician faces time when the network is not running up to par. We will take a look at different utilities and techniques to identify network  issues like routing delays, DNS issues, DHCP failures and end-to-end communications. We demonstrate some of the utilities that can be used to not only identify but resolve issues that arise on the network.
name: Network Troubleshooting
subtitle: Command Line Tools for Diagnosing Network Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes show you how to troubleshoot common network issues using command line tools. Specific tools covered include ipconfig, ping, and tracert.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting with CMD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.236 --> 00:00:17.113
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.113 --> 00:00:18.990
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.990 --> 00:00:22.600
in today's episode we are taking
a look at network troubleshooting.

5
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:25.370
Joining us today to help us
out with that very endeavor,

6
00:00:25.370 --> 00:00:27.890
is none other than our good friend,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:27.890 --> 00:00:28.830
Wes, welcome to the show, sir.

8
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:30.780
How's it going?
>> It's going great, and as always,

9
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:32.060
Dan, it's great to be back here.

10
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:35.890
And that's right, we're gonna look at
a little bit of the command line and

11
00:00:35.890 --> 00:00:39.390
see what we got going on when it comes
to the world of troubleshooting.

12
00:00:39.390 --> 00:00:41.318
So, tell you what,
let's go ahead and dive in.

13
00:00:41.318 --> 00:00:45.944
And Dan, one of the first commands I think
when I think of just understanding about

14
00:00:45.944 --> 00:00:50.680
the networking communications in general,
is gonna be good old trusty ipconfig.

15
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:54.100
Now, we've probably seen this before in
other episodes and if you haven't, well,

16
00:00:54.100 --> 00:00:55.440
that's good that you're here.

17
00:00:55.440 --> 00:00:58.710
We gotta keep in mind that we got a lot of
good episodes on networking that can show

18
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:00.840
you really in depth about ipconfig.

19
00:01:00.840 --> 00:01:03.100
So what is ipconfig for us?

20
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:05.890
Well that's the internet
protocol configuration utility.

21
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:08.660
And what we use it for
primarily is to look and

22
00:01:08.660 --> 00:01:11.860
see the parameters,
TCP/IP parameters of our network adapter.

23
00:01:11.860 --> 00:01:15.140
Now let's take the geek speak and all
the acronyms and alphabet soup out of it.

24
00:01:15.140 --> 00:01:16.110
What does that mean for us?

25
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:18.310
Well, we have to have an IP address,
right,

26
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:20.590
to communicate across
the TCP/IP based network.

27
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:23.170
So this is one of the first
utilities that lets us know well,

28
00:01:23.170 --> 00:01:24.510
what are those settings, Dan?

29
00:01:24.510 --> 00:01:26.980
So I think we'll just go ahead and
dive right in here and see what we have.

30
00:01:26.980 --> 00:01:32.320
So I've got a command prompt pulled up and
I'm just gonna type ipconfig.

31
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:37.250
Now if I just type ipconfig by itself it's
gonna give me some basic information.

32
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:40.020
Now you have to pay attention to
which network adapter you have, and

33
00:01:40.020 --> 00:01:43.730
it starts to get a little confusing
sometimes when you couple in

34
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:48.390
things like maybe wireless adapter and
a wired adapter, and then Bluetooth.

35
00:01:48.390 --> 00:01:50.990
And you should see some
IPv6 here going on,

36
00:01:50.990 --> 00:01:55.440
Toredo and some of those other adapters
and technologies that are out there.

37
00:01:55.440 --> 00:01:59.780
The ones that we really are concerned
with, specifically in a TCP/IP v4 network,

38
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:01.970
is gonna be the one that
you see right here.

39
00:02:01.970 --> 00:02:04.160
And if you notice, we have what?

40
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:07.070
We have our Ethernet adapter Ethernet0.

41
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:11.480
Right, Ethernet0 is the name
of the local area connection.

42
00:02:11.480 --> 00:02:14.800
Now you might, out there, look and
see local area connection.

43
00:02:14.800 --> 00:02:16.260
Right, that's pretty standard here.

44
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:17.370
Now, I'm in a virtual machine.

45
00:02:17.370 --> 00:02:20.850
So, kind of renames the network
virtualized adapters a little bit

46
00:02:20.850 --> 00:02:22.990
differently, but that's all it is,
it's just a name.

47
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:25.510
It's gonna look maybe the local
area connection for you.

48
00:02:25.510 --> 00:02:28.420
Now Dan, one of the first things I have
to find out is if I do have network

49
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:29.530
connection problems, right?

50
00:02:29.530 --> 00:02:31.980
If I don't have communication, right?

51
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:34.630
I'm gonna probably check here, right?

52
00:02:34.630 --> 00:02:38.210
I'm probably gonna check the IP
address cuz I have to have one.

53
00:02:38.210 --> 00:02:39.780
Now Dan,
you mentioned something earlier, right?

54
00:02:39.780 --> 00:02:40.830
If we are gonna check for

55
00:02:40.830 --> 00:02:44.780
network communications, ipconfig might
not be the first place I go, right?

56
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:49.496
>> Yeah, usually it's really a good idea
to actually check your cable stuff first.

57
00:02:49.496 --> 00:02:50.642
It happens all the time.

58
00:02:50.642 --> 00:02:54.580
No, that's not specifically a command line
function, obviously we're in the physical

59
00:02:54.580 --> 00:02:58.115
realm and that's kind of a virtual thing,
digitized, as it were.

60
00:02:58.115 --> 00:03:01.825
But it does happen a lot, maybe you moved
your desk, maybe you said, you know what,

61
00:03:01.825 --> 00:03:05.357
my computer would look better over here or
it'd be more functional.

62
00:03:05.357 --> 00:03:09.463
And now I got a different office, awesome,
I'm migrating over there for all my stuff,

63
00:03:09.463 --> 00:03:11.200
and you forgot to plug that cable in.

64
00:03:11.200 --> 00:03:13.818
That is one thing that'll stop you
dead in your tracks every time,

65
00:03:13.818 --> 00:03:17.540
you're not gonna get much connectivity
if your cable isn't actually plugged in.

66
00:03:17.540 --> 00:03:19.690
Might be on a wireless network,
that could happen, right?

67
00:03:19.690 --> 00:03:23.420
But if you are on a wired network,
check both ends of the cable, right,

68
00:03:23.420 --> 00:03:27.050
make sure that they are securely seated,
listen for that click, and

69
00:03:27.050 --> 00:03:28.640
then if you're still having trouble,

70
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:32.445
just make sure that there's no
obvious places inside that cable.

71
00:03:32.445 --> 00:03:36.070
Where maybe you ran it over with
a chair and now it's cut inside.

72
00:03:36.070 --> 00:03:38.710
Maybe it didn't cut through but
it's broken the wires, and such.

73
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:40.400
Just look for damage to the cable.

74
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:44.450
These are simple starting
points that you want to check.

75
00:03:44.450 --> 00:03:46.560
If you realize, hey,
maybe I did some moving.

76
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:47.780
Maybe there is a physical problem.

77
00:03:47.780 --> 00:03:51.230
You might just want to go there first,
but other than that, ipconfig,

78
00:03:51.230 --> 00:03:54.330
that's definitely where we're gonna start,
because we got to see whether or

79
00:03:54.330 --> 00:03:57.840
not, we're even on a network and
ipconfig and lets us do that.

80
00:03:57.840 --> 00:03:58.660
>> That's exactly it.

81
00:03:58.660 --> 00:04:01.760
So while we were getting that explanation,
I went ahead and move about five or

82
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:05.500
six computers and
forgot to plug in their network adapters.

83
00:04:05.500 --> 00:04:06.130
Okay, just kidding.

84
00:04:06.130 --> 00:04:09.280
But we went ahead and set up a scenario,
what would it look like if

85
00:04:09.280 --> 00:04:12.390
the media was disconnected inside
a command prompt with ipconfig?

86
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:15.210
Let's check that out here, so
I'm gonna rerun the command.

87
00:04:15.210 --> 00:04:15.890
All right,

88
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:20.580
and the very first thing you notice right
here is media is disconnected, all right?

89
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:24.438
So, first of all, I don't have an IP
address, so then I can tell that's

90
00:04:24.438 --> 00:04:28.579
gotta be a problem here and I don't
even see anything, I see no information.

91
00:04:28.579 --> 00:04:33.570
I don't see a MAC address or anything,
so I can also check down here.

92
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:36.800
My head's kind of covering it up, but down
here at the bottom you got that little

93
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:39.700
monitor icon, and notice,
I gotta get my hand out of the way there.

94
00:04:39.700 --> 00:04:41.060
Notice how there's a little red x on it,

95
00:04:41.060 --> 00:04:43.180
that lets me know that
the media's disconnected.

96
00:04:43.180 --> 00:04:46.050
And if I go into the Network and
Sharing Center, I'm gonna go ahead and

97
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:48.990
just re-enable this and
then we'll get out of the GUI here and

98
00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:50.900
get back to the command prompt.

99
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:53.990
All right, now notice the difference
here once I rerun this command.

100
00:04:53.990 --> 00:04:58.710
Notice when I do an ipconfig,
well, I get an IP address here.

101
00:04:58.710 --> 00:05:01.320
I get a subnet mask and
I get my default gateway, and

102
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:03.440
these are all important things.

103
00:05:03.440 --> 00:05:08.035
It is a necessity to have an IP address
and the right subnet mask communicate on

104
00:05:08.035 --> 00:05:11.585
your local network,
if you want to go across your network.

105
00:05:11.585 --> 00:05:14.856
Maybe for you home viewers out there, you
want to go communicate out there across

106
00:05:14.856 --> 00:05:17.780
the Internet, then the default
gateway is gonna be important, too.

107
00:05:17.780 --> 00:05:22.110
Some other information in here, as well,
but this is definitely gonna be the start.

108
00:05:22.110 --> 00:05:25.520
Now, If you need to see
additional information, right?

109
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:29.880
More information than just what ipconfig
gets, well we got a switch now, right?

110
00:05:29.880 --> 00:05:33.570
We add the switch with a /all.

111
00:05:34.632 --> 00:05:38.000
All right now,
this is a ton of information guys, so

112
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:41.660
you'll see a lot of IPV6
translational technologies.

113
00:05:41.660 --> 00:05:44.630
Now I see my Bluetooth adapter here.

114
00:05:44.630 --> 00:05:49.690
But notice that in the ethernet
adapter area, notice that I get a lot

115
00:05:49.690 --> 00:05:53.200
of additional information that
wasn't there before, right?

116
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:57.610
I get information on, am I using DHCP,
and if I follow this information over,

117
00:05:57.610 --> 00:06:00.440
right, I can see that,
yeah, DHCP is enabled.

118
00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:05.241
So if for some reason I don't have an IP
address, all right, well, I can probably

119
00:06:05.241 --> 00:06:10.133
say that it doesn't have to do with the
fact that my computer's configured wrong.

120
00:06:10.133 --> 00:06:14.196
I might want to check out my home router
or something, maybe that's being blocked,

121
00:06:14.196 --> 00:06:17.420
right, and we could even show you
what that might look like, too.

122
00:06:17.420 --> 00:06:22.420
If I come in here and I do an ipconfig and
I do a release, all right,

123
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:25.240
basically what I'm telling this
network adapter is I'm saying,

124
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:27.430
I know the DHCP server's
giving an IP address.

125
00:06:27.430 --> 00:06:29.750
I just want you to let it go, all right?

126
00:06:29.750 --> 00:06:30.580
Let it go, man.

127
00:06:30.580 --> 00:06:32.390
And we're gonna go ahead and
run an /all here.

128
00:06:32.390 --> 00:06:35.840
And now you're gonna notice
a little bit different here, right?

129
00:06:35.840 --> 00:06:37.880
Notice that DHCP is still enabled.

130
00:06:37.880 --> 00:06:38.780
Right, nothing has changed.

131
00:06:38.780 --> 00:06:43.080
I still have DHCP, but now I'm getting
what is known as an APIPA address, right?

132
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:44.980
Now an APIPA address, understand.

133
00:06:44.980 --> 00:06:48.360
And Dan made a good point as we were
taking behind the scenes here that

134
00:06:48.360 --> 00:06:50.410
APIPA in and
of itself isn't a tool, right?

135
00:06:50.410 --> 00:06:51.570
It's not a utility.

136
00:06:51.570 --> 00:06:54.140
But it could be indicative of
a problem that you're having with

137
00:06:54.140 --> 00:06:55.930
your DHCP server, right?

138
00:06:55.930 --> 00:06:59.460
My computer now is calling out to the
network and it's saying, hey DHCP server,

139
00:06:59.460 --> 00:07:00.660
are you out there?

140
00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:02.490
I could really use an IP address, right?

141
00:07:02.490 --> 00:07:07.180
Now, I kind of created this problem here,
but this would look no different, right?

142
00:07:07.180 --> 00:07:09.730
So it's calling out and
the DHCP server is snoozing.

143
00:07:09.730 --> 00:07:11.460
Well, that's a problem.

144
00:07:11.460 --> 00:07:15.170
Now what if I know that I've
rebooted the DHCP server?

145
00:07:15.170 --> 00:07:17.590
I know it's online but
I still don't have an IP address.

146
00:07:17.590 --> 00:07:18.970
Well, you seen the release, right?

147
00:07:18.970 --> 00:07:21.560
Sometimes you get a sticky lease where the
computer just doesn't want to let it go,

148
00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:26.070
or you want to force the DHCP
process to start over again.

149
00:07:26.070 --> 00:07:29.180
Well that's when we change that,
and let me clear the screen and

150
00:07:29.180 --> 00:07:32.090
get towards the top so
you guys can see that a little easier,

151
00:07:32.090 --> 00:07:38.210
now this is where I want to change
that switch to renew, right?

152
00:07:38.210 --> 00:07:38.960
Now what's gonna happen?

153
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:41.308
When I change it to renew,
it's gonna take a second.

154
00:07:41.308 --> 00:07:43.170
Now you're gonna see something,
an error out here,

155
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:47.340
Bluetooth is not going to receive an IP
address, and you should be able to see it.

156
00:07:47.340 --> 00:07:51.180
This operation can't be performed in
the Bluetooth network connection.

157
00:07:51.180 --> 00:07:52.310
It's an expected error, right?

158
00:07:52.310 --> 00:07:54.115
We're not using DHCP on Bluetooth.

159
00:07:54.115 --> 00:07:59.325
But what I do see now is that I've got
an IP address again, and if I get a little

160
00:07:59.325 --> 00:08:04.874
bit more information I can say that yes,
again, DHCP is still enabled, right?

161
00:08:04.874 --> 00:08:08.190
Oops, there we go, DHCP is still enabled.

162
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:12.850
I do have an IP address and now I also
have what's known as an active lease.

163
00:08:12.850 --> 00:08:16.850
Kinda like a car rental agreement,
right, or I'm gonna be in town for

164
00:08:16.850 --> 00:08:19.010
a while, I'm gonna be using this car,
I've got the car for a week,

165
00:08:19.010 --> 00:08:21.360
same thing happens with your IP addresses.

166
00:08:21.360 --> 00:08:24.970
So Dan, ipconfig, ipconfig all,
ipconfig release and

167
00:08:24.970 --> 00:08:30.160
renew All good switches inside of
the IP Configuration utility, or

168
00:08:30.160 --> 00:08:34.810
IPConfig utility that can help you start
on your network troubleshooting journey.

169
00:08:34.810 --> 00:08:38.670
>> Yeah, it's, like I say, it's a great
place to begin, because you start getting

170
00:08:38.670 --> 00:08:42.580
an idea of the network connectivity
that your device actually has.

171
00:08:42.580 --> 00:08:44.000
We saw it with Ethernet Zero.

172
00:08:44.000 --> 00:08:44.720
We looked at it.

173
00:08:44.720 --> 00:08:47.430
IPConfig's giving me an IP
address Subnet mask.

174
00:08:47.430 --> 00:08:49.030
All the good stuff was there.

175
00:08:49.030 --> 00:08:51.640
Now, sometimes, you're setup for DHCP.

176
00:08:51.640 --> 00:08:54.170
You plug in, you turn on.

177
00:08:54.170 --> 00:08:57.411
Okay, my cables are good, but
I still can't contact the network.

178
00:08:57.411 --> 00:08:58.640
Do an ipconfig.

179
00:08:58.640 --> 00:09:00.060
I have an IP address.

180
00:09:00.060 --> 00:09:02.270
I still can't do any kind of connectivity.

181
00:09:02.270 --> 00:09:05.830
The problem is it might just be set to
at static address, That does happen,

182
00:09:05.830 --> 00:09:09.360
maybe someone came in and configured,
maybe you did it during some testing.

183
00:09:09.360 --> 00:09:10.090
This happens.

184
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:11.060
I've had it happen to me.

185
00:09:11.060 --> 00:09:16.320
You just forget that I had this thing set
for a static address for whatever reason.

186
00:09:16.320 --> 00:09:20.380
Now I wanted to get a DHCP address, you
gotta go back in, you gotta change that.

187
00:09:20.380 --> 00:09:22.630
Now that's not necessarily done
through the command line...

188
00:09:22.630 --> 00:09:25.270
you can do it and
we might even actually talk about that.

189
00:09:25.270 --> 00:09:30.070
But, using IP config is gonna let you
know, I'm not on the correct network.

190
00:09:30.070 --> 00:09:34.480
I've got a static IP outside of the range
of the network that I'm on right now.

191
00:09:34.480 --> 00:09:35.510
It's not valid.

192
00:09:35.510 --> 00:09:37.980
So, just using IP config is
gonna allow you to see that and

193
00:09:37.980 --> 00:09:40.100
go, yes, I'm set for static.

194
00:09:40.100 --> 00:09:43.100
I'm need to change that to DHCP and
now I should be good to go.

195
00:09:43.100 --> 00:09:45.835
So even though it's a very simple tool.

196
00:09:45.835 --> 00:09:47.520
Right?
It just gives you output.

197
00:09:47.520 --> 00:09:50.750
You do have a few functional keys with it.

198
00:09:50.750 --> 00:09:53.130
It's got some switches you can
throw at it and do some things.

199
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:56.470
But normally, you're just using it for
informational, or just hey,

200
00:09:56.470 --> 00:09:58.890
release that and renew me another one.

201
00:09:58.890 --> 00:10:02.640
Wes, is there anything else when it comes
to IP config that we can learn about.

202
00:10:02.640 --> 00:10:05.870
>> There really is, and there
are a ton of switches, like Dan says.

203
00:10:05.870 --> 00:10:09.740
There are a couple that I wanna point out,
because we're gonna talk more about this

204
00:10:09.740 --> 00:10:12.770
troubleshooting, troubleshooting
this service coming up as well.

205
00:10:12.770 --> 00:10:16.841
But DNS, DNS might be something that,
you know, DNS Domain Name System, keep in

206
00:10:16.841 --> 00:10:20.747
mind it just takes our user friendly names
and maps them to their IP addresses.

207
00:10:20.747 --> 00:10:23.531
So if we want to contact websites
out there across the world,

208
00:10:23.531 --> 00:10:27.243
well Dan doesn't have to break out that
old 50 pound book of all the IP addresses

209
00:10:27.243 --> 00:10:31.070
that he has written out, because you
know we couldn't remember them all.

210
00:10:31.070 --> 00:10:33.050
Right, so DNS does name resolution for us.

211
00:10:33.050 --> 00:10:34.340
Well, you might say,
well wait a second, Wes,

212
00:10:34.340 --> 00:10:38.010
I thought you just said IP
configuration utility, right?

213
00:10:38.010 --> 00:10:39.590
Well what does that have
to do with anything?

214
00:10:39.590 --> 00:10:41.580
Well, DNS has a lot to do with it, right?

215
00:10:41.580 --> 00:10:46.230
If I type a name in,
I can't visit the website by its name, but

216
00:10:46.230 --> 00:10:48.140
I type in its IP address
cuz I happen to know it,

217
00:10:48.140 --> 00:10:53.150
then I know there's a problem with DNS And
that's where ipconfig display DNS.

670
00:31:47.540 --> 00:31:51.010
We have all the different hops
that my packets are taking

671
00:31:51.010 --> 00:31:52.260
to get to their destination.

672
00:31:52.260 --> 00:31:54.720
If you ultimately get to trace complete,
well,

673
00:31:54.720 --> 00:31:56.070
you're getting to where
you're wanting to go.

674
00:31:56.070 --> 00:31:58.645
You might have some of those
failures like Wes showed you.

675
00:31:58.645 --> 00:32:02.165
But it just means they're probably
not replying to that information.

676
00:32:02.165 --> 00:32:04.210
It's saying stand off, usually a firewall,

677
00:32:04.210 --> 00:32:07.460
maybe it just doesn't have that feature
turned on, and that's what's happening.

678
00:32:07.460 --> 00:32:09.870
But as long as you get to the end of it,
you should be good to go,

679
00:32:09.870 --> 00:32:11.500
you have connectivity.

680
00:32:11.500 --> 00:32:15.624
But if you're not having connectivity, you
never get trace complete and it stops, and

681
00:32:15.624 --> 00:32:16.292
it stops, and

682
00:32:16.292 --> 00:32:19.989
it stops and it never keeps going, well
at least you know where the problem is.

683
00:32:19.989 --> 00:32:21.451
You go to your provider if
that's were it might be.

684
00:32:21.451 --> 00:32:25.398
If it's outside your provider's network,
maybe the information is in there where

685
00:32:25.398 --> 00:32:29.250
it's stopped and you can call them and
say, are you having a problem with outage?

686
00:32:29.250 --> 00:32:31.880
People dig through optic
cables all the time.

687
00:32:31.880 --> 00:32:34.445
And I've seen the whole state, sides, and

688
00:32:34.445 --> 00:32:39.036
the entire state of Florida go down
before because entire providers are done.

689
00:32:39.036 --> 00:32:42.972
Something happened with their fiber
backbone and that's the end of it.

690
00:32:42.972 --> 00:32:44.704
And you'll see that when
you start the traceroute.

691
00:32:44.704 --> 00:32:47.057
You're saying,
okay well I can get to my network,

692
00:32:47.057 --> 00:32:49.440
I can even get outside ov
my network a certain bit.

693
00:32:49.440 --> 00:32:51.040
But where am I stopping?

694
00:32:51.040 --> 00:32:53.060
It's with my provider, let me call them.

695
00:32:53.060 --> 00:32:54.460
Are you having any issues?

696
00:32:54.460 --> 00:32:58.670
They'll verify, yep, we had a guy,
didn't call before he dug, and

697
00:32:58.670 --> 00:33:02.890
sliced right through our fiber
backbone and we're having issues.

698
00:33:02.890 --> 00:33:04.815
At that point, it is,
it's out of your hands,

699
00:33:04.815 --> 00:33:06.368
there's nothing you can do but wait.

700
00:33:06.368 --> 00:33:11.343
You got an SLA with your provider, they're
gonna give you some sort of compensation

701
00:33:11.343 --> 00:33:16.748
for that, sometimes, as long it's outside
of the realms of what they expect to see.

702
00:33:16.748 --> 00:33:18.150
But then there's nothing
you can really do,

703
00:33:18.150 --> 00:33:21.160
wait until that connectivity comes back.

704
00:33:21.160 --> 00:33:24.815
Now Wes, we've got a few more tools
that we wanna go through, but

705
00:33:24.815 --> 00:33:26.855
that clock is well done.

706
00:33:26.855 --> 00:33:28.515
We went well past it.

707
00:33:28.515 --> 00:33:30.968
So it looks like we're gonna have to have
a part two on network troubleshooting with

708
00:33:30.968 --> 00:33:31.608
command line tools.

709
00:33:31.608 --> 00:33:32.908
>> That sounds good,
it looks like we killed the clock.

710
00:33:32.908 --> 00:33:33.628
>> Yeah we sure did.

711
00:33:33.628 --> 00:33:35.137
>> [LAUGH]
>> Look forward to seeing you there.

712
00:33:35.137 --> 00:33:35.647
>> Definitely.

713
00:33:35.647 --> 00:33:36.344
>> Thanks for stopping by.

714
00:33:36.344 --> 00:33:37.875
Thank you guys for watching.

715
00:33:37.875 --> 00:33:39.185
Hopefully we'll see you in part two.

716
00:33:39.185 --> 00:33:41.534
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

717
00:33:41.534 --> 00:33:42.825
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

718
00:33:42.825 --> 00:33:43.655
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

719
00:33:43.655 --> 00:33:44.585
>> We'll see you next time.

720
00:33:44.585 --> 00:33:53.120
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes show you how to troubleshoot common network issues using command line tools. Specific tools covered include netstat, netsh, and nslookup.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting with CMD Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.950 --> 00:00:10.950
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.448 --> 00:00:17.230
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.230 --> 00:00:20.290
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on with

4
00:00:20.290 --> 00:00:23.950
our network troubleshooting,
using command line tools.

5
00:00:23.950 --> 00:00:27.271
Joining us back in the studio again today
to help us out with that very endeavor,

6
00:00:27.271 --> 00:00:29.364
none other than our good friend,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:29.364 --> 00:00:30.800
Wes, welcome back to the show sir.

8
00:00:30.800 --> 00:00:32.800
>> Hey, thanks for
having me here, and that's right.

9
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:35.400
Apparently, I talked way too
much in the first episode.

10
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:39.320
So we're coming at you with, well, the
sequel here today, cuz we do have a few

11
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:43.690
more, just a couple more utilities that
we wouldn't really be doing you justice,

12
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:45.870
if we didn't mention and
put in the episode here.

13
00:00:45.870 --> 00:00:47.690
So, let's go ahead and
talk about a couple of them.

14
00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:50.197
One that I really want to talk
about right going out the gate,

15
00:00:50.197 --> 00:00:51.880
is gonna be something known as netstat.

16
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:54.200
Now that's short for network statistic.

17
00:00:54.200 --> 00:00:56.704
Now, there's a couple different
reasons you might use this.

18
00:00:56.704 --> 00:01:00.054
One of the primary reasons I
know that I've used it before,

19
00:01:00.054 --> 00:01:01.528
is to look and determine,

20
00:01:01.528 --> 00:01:05.559
what are the state of the connections
that I have on my machine, right?

21
00:01:05.559 --> 00:01:07.703
And when we talk about connections,
typically,

22
00:01:07.703 --> 00:01:10.469
we're talking about
Transmission Control Protocol, right?

23
00:01:10.469 --> 00:01:11.810
Connection-oriented service.

24
00:01:11.810 --> 00:01:15.123
And I wanna see if I can establish
a connection, maybe to a server, or

25
00:01:15.123 --> 00:01:18.722
if I already have an established
connection, not only to web servers, but

26
00:01:18.722 --> 00:01:21.600
to other services that you have
running in the background.

27
00:01:21.600 --> 00:01:24.350
For instance, if you're connected
to shared resources as well.

28
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:25.490
Let me go show you what I mean here.

29
00:01:25.490 --> 00:01:29.486
So we've got the network's,
I say network's statistics utility, but

30
00:01:29.486 --> 00:01:32.011
let's be careful with that one guys,
right?

31
00:01:32.011 --> 00:01:34.890
That is the netstat they
just abbreviated there.

32
00:01:34.890 --> 00:01:40.410
We're gonna use the -a switch, and
that just means show me everything.

33
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:42.970
I'm gonna show you a couple different
switches here that you might like.

34
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:46.991
For instance, I might do this a little bit
differently then just, sometimes they just

35
00:01:46.991 --> 00:01:51.270
say, -a, that shows me everything, all
the connections in their current state.

36
00:01:51.270 --> 00:01:54.826
And you can see some over here
in this right-hand column.

37
00:01:54.826 --> 00:01:57.192
You'll notice that it says that yeah,
they're listening.

38
00:01:57.192 --> 00:02:00.019
And if we scroll down just
a little bit farther here,

39
00:02:00.019 --> 00:02:03.240
we could see that there are some
established connections.

40
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:04.249
It looks like it got done there.

41
00:02:05.290 --> 00:02:08.060
So we do see that there are some
established connections here, and

42
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:10.020
we can find IP addresses here.

43
00:02:10.020 --> 00:02:14.080
In fact, there should be a couple in here
that might even be related to things like

44
00:02:14.080 --> 00:02:15.380
SMB connections too.

45
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:18.333
So, if Dan's got a file server
out there in Windows, and

46
00:02:18.333 --> 00:02:20.995
I'm connected to it, well that's still
an established connection, right?

47
00:02:20.995 --> 00:02:24.200
And I would see that fact here,
and maybe that's what I'm doing.

48
00:02:24.200 --> 00:02:26.312
Maybe I'm troubleshooting a connection,
if you will,

49
00:02:26.312 --> 00:02:27.854
to something like a file server, right?

50
00:02:27.854 --> 00:02:30.208
And I wanna know,
do I have to establish a connection?

51
00:02:30.208 --> 00:02:32.517
I can say, well on this computer,
if I run netstat -a,

52
00:02:32.517 --> 00:02:34.620
I can say that I had a connection, right?

53
00:02:34.620 --> 00:02:36.144
Maybe the next computer
that I'm troubleshooting,

54
00:02:36.144 --> 00:02:40.205
I run a netstat space -a, and
I don't get that connection, and

55
00:02:40.205 --> 00:02:44.190
that'd maybe give me an idea of where
I want to troubleshoot from there.

56
00:02:44.190 --> 00:02:47.900
But one of the things that might help you
out too, is you can also filter this down,

57
00:02:47.900 --> 00:02:51.602
and Dan as you can see, right,
we got a lot of stuff for UDP.

58
00:02:51.602 --> 00:02:56.090
And as we know, UDP, User Datagram
Protocol, it's a connectionless service,

59
00:02:56.090 --> 00:02:57.510
it's best ever delivery.

60
00:02:57.510 --> 00:03:00.280
So it makes no established connection,
right?

61
00:03:00.280 --> 00:03:02.270
So it's not gonna give us any information.

62
00:03:02.270 --> 00:03:05.715
Well, if it's not gonna give us any
information, why put it in the list?

63
00:03:05.715 --> 00:03:08.545
Well, it might be important
information for you, you never know.

64
00:03:08.545 --> 00:03:10.030
Nothing like seeing nothing.

65
00:03:10.030 --> 00:03:13.195
[LAUGH] So we're gonna go ahead, let me
clear this and get this back to the top of

66
00:03:13.195 --> 00:03:15.495
the screen, guys,
make it a little easier for you to see.

67
00:03:15.495 --> 00:03:21.310
We're gonna do a netstat, and I can
actually do a switch p, for protocol.

68
00:03:21.310 --> 00:03:23.880
And I could say, okay,
I just wanna see TCP.

69
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:27.470
And what it's gonna do, is it's gonna look
through all those connections that we just

70
00:03:27.470 --> 00:03:30.180
had, right, but
it'll filter the list a little bit faster.

71
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:32.870
You see it kinda went through
it a little bit quicker there.

72
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:35.530
Because I'm really just worried
about the TCP connections, and

73
00:03:35.530 --> 00:03:36.850
what their current state is.

74
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:39.520
I don't care about all
the User Datagram Protocol information.

75
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:42.500
And I can get to that
information a little bit faster.

76
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:44.750
Now, you could do a little bit
more of information for this.

77
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:46.520
Like I said,
it's a really powerful utility.

78
00:03:46.520 --> 00:03:49.330
For instance, maybe I wanna see
the statistics of the ethernet adapter

79
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:50.820
themselves, right?

80
00:03:50.820 --> 00:03:53.330
Not a little higher in
the OSI model there.

81
00:03:53.330 --> 00:03:56.520
I don't really care about transmission
control protocol, maybe, per se.

82
00:03:56.520 --> 00:04:00.380
Well, I can always do a netstat -a,
and you can remember it for -ethernet.

83
00:04:00.380 --> 00:04:01.400
That's how I remember it.

84
00:04:01.400 --> 00:04:03.580
If you're ever out there at
a certification endeavor,

85
00:04:03.580 --> 00:04:07.340
some of you guys that have taken your
certs know that it's 1001 standards and

86
00:04:07.340 --> 00:04:11.170
acronyms you gotta remember,
it'd help you remember, a -e for ethernet.

87
00:04:11.170 --> 00:04:13.770
And what I can do is,
I can see some basic ethernet

88
00:04:13.770 --> 00:04:16.520
interface statistics is what it says,
but the interface is ethernet.

89
00:04:16.520 --> 00:04:21.410
And I could see unicast packets, I could
see non-unicast packets, and maybe I'm,

90
00:04:21.410 --> 00:04:26.000
even though this is not as prevalent
today in modern networks as it would have

91
00:04:26.000 --> 00:04:29.240
been maybe in older networks, maybe I'm
looking for broadcast storms, right?

92
00:04:29.240 --> 00:04:31.244
And I see non-unicast packets.

93
00:04:31.244 --> 00:04:33.590
Non-unicast is gonna be lumped together,
right?

94
00:04:33.590 --> 00:04:36.130
So it's not the only type of
communication that we have.

95
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:40.200
It's not just unicast, but I might
see some broadcast information here.

96
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:42.143
Or maybe I've got some errors going on,
and

97
00:04:42.143 --> 00:04:44.040
I can see something's not playing right.

98
00:04:44.040 --> 00:04:46.327
We're getting some kind of corruption,
right?

99
00:04:46.327 --> 00:04:48.944
And my computer's sending back
to the source saying, hey,

100
00:04:48.944 --> 00:04:50.240
negative acknowledgement.

101
00:04:50.240 --> 00:04:53.170
We've got some kind of error,
retransmit that information.

102
00:04:53.170 --> 00:04:56.500
And that can also lead to performance
degradation too as well, right?

103
00:04:56.500 --> 00:05:01.360
Any time you've gotta send a packet twice,
it's just retransmission.

104
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:02.842
It could cause delay, or

105
00:05:02.842 --> 00:05:07.377
it could cause just an overwhelming
amount of information on your network.

106
00:05:07.377 --> 00:05:08.860
So netstat, Dan, kinda cool.

107
00:05:08.860 --> 00:05:11.220
Let me give you a little

108
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:14.670
bit more information here on what's going
in the background, because we ran it, and

109
00:05:14.670 --> 00:05:16.550
I really didn't tell you
the information here.

110
00:05:16.550 --> 00:05:19.320
You notice that there's some
connections that are established?

111
00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:22.610
I can see that this is a connection
to our storage location, right?

112
00:05:22.610 --> 00:05:25.240
And I how do I know that
that's my computer?

113
00:05:25.240 --> 00:05:28.690
Well first of all,
you notice it says local address, right?

114
00:05:28.690 --> 00:05:30.120
So here's my local IP address.

115
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:33.440
I can see that this is a high-level
port value that's on the end of it.

116
00:05:33.440 --> 00:05:37.130
So I can see that this is a temporary
connection that my computer's established,

117
00:05:37.130 --> 00:05:40.720
and you can get that information
right out of what you're seeing here.

118
00:05:40.720 --> 00:05:44.060
I know it's kinda hard to see out there,
but I'm gonna hover it over right here,

119
00:05:44.060 --> 00:05:47.260
notice that we have Chrome
going in the background, and

120
00:05:47.260 --> 00:05:49.080
I've got a connection here.

121
00:05:49.080 --> 00:05:53.940
Try to get that out of the way, it always
wants me to start that up, or show it.

122
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:58.580
And you can see that I got an established
connection out there to Google as well,

123
00:05:58.580 --> 00:05:59.760
out to their servers.

124
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:04.300
So, it's good to test the connections and
see what the state of the connections are.

125
00:06:04.300 --> 00:06:07.400
So that's why netstat, definitely
put it in your tech tool bag, and

126
00:06:07.400 --> 00:06:08.940
I would know it if you're troubleshooting.

127
00:06:08.940 --> 00:06:11.800
>> Yeah, it's really handy
when it comes to figuring out,

128
00:06:11.800 --> 00:06:14.630
why am I having some
network slowdown issues?

129
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:16.360
It can help in that endeavor.

130
00:06:16.360 --> 00:06:21.250
Specifically on, or I should say
especially, on client computers.

131
00:06:21.250 --> 00:06:24.760
Cuz a lot of times they'll get programs
they weren't intending to get.

132
00:06:24.760 --> 00:06:26.040
We like to call this malware.

133
00:06:26.040 --> 00:06:28.130
It's really great for
helping you find that.

134
00:06:28.130 --> 00:06:30.180
If someone says, man,
my computer's running slow,

135
00:06:30.180 --> 00:06:33.160
I always ask, is the computer running
slower, or is the network running slower?

136
00:06:33.160 --> 00:06:34.770
Is the Internet connectivity slow?

137
00:06:34.770 --> 00:06:36.492
Well, it's anytime I access the Internet.

138
00:06:36.492 --> 00:06:38.718
Okay, let's check your
network connectivity.

139
00:06:38.718 --> 00:06:41.982
Sometimes I'll run netstat there and
see, let's check and

140
00:06:41.982 --> 00:06:43.779
see what you're connecting to.

141
00:06:43.779 --> 00:06:48.259
And if I see some weird activity
happening, I might look that up,

142
00:06:48.259 --> 00:06:52.910
and we'll lookup where it is
they're actually contacting.

143
00:06:52.910 --> 00:06:56.180
Look.
It's a Romanian server somewhere.

144
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:57.970
Look at this nice Chinese server here.

145
00:06:57.970 --> 00:07:01.220
You might have a hacker going on, so
it's really good for picking up that.

146
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:05.170
Or, if your computers just gone haywire,
maybe your network card is just

147
00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:09.240
flooding the network with traffic,
I can see that, using the statistics.

148
00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:10.868
So, very handy little tool.

149
00:07:10.868 --> 00:07:12.861
Definitely one that you
wanna have in the kit.

150
00:07:12.861 --> 00:07:13.950
>> Yeah, true.

151
00:07:13.950 --> 00:07:18.100
And with Transmission Control Protocol
being that connection-oriented state, Dan,

152
00:07:18.100 --> 00:07:21.708
too, you might think of things like
denial-of-service attacks, right?

153
00:07:21.708 --> 00:07:25.831
Cuz in the whole communication
with TCP/IP, it's gonna wait for

154
00:07:25.831 --> 00:07:29.596
the last piece of a handshake
to establish that connection.

155
00:07:29.596 --> 00:07:32.273
And if that connection is
gonna be just withheld,

156
00:07:32.273 --> 00:07:36.930
then what happens is your computer starts
having all these established connections,

157
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:40.753
and before you know it, you're out of RAM,
you're out of memory, and

158
00:07:40.753 --> 00:07:43.203
worst case scenario your computer reboots.

159
00:07:43.203 --> 00:07:47.470
So a lot of good, handy information
to have, and I would be aware of it.

160
00:07:47.470 --> 00:07:52.199
Now, there is another one that's out there
that we need to be aware of, in general,

161
00:07:52.199 --> 00:07:54.076
and this is for name resolution.

162
00:07:54.076 --> 00:07:56.215
Keep in mind,
in the first part of this episode,

163
00:07:56.215 --> 00:07:58.784
we did talk about some handy
utilities that you could use.

164
00:07:58.784 --> 00:08:03.727
We talked about ipconfig, right, and
the displaydns to see the local resolver

165
00:08:03.727 --> 00:08:07.210
cache, and
the flushdns to clear that resolver cache.

166
00:08:07.210 --> 00:08:10.997
Well, there's another one out there that
you need to be aware of that helps test

167
00:08:10.997 --> 00:08:12.970
name resolution, and his is nslookup.

168
00:08:12.970 --> 00:08:16.190
Nslookup is short for name server lookup.

169
00:08:16.190 --> 00:08:19.600
If you guys are in other NIC-based
systems, I believe they have DIG, right,

170
00:08:19.600 --> 00:08:21.010
the domain internet groper.

171
00:08:21.010 --> 00:08:25.520
So what we need to do is we need
to find out if I send a request to

172
00:08:25.520 --> 00:08:29.600
a DNS server,
will it resolve it for me, right?

173

394
00:19:54.390 --> 00:19:55.670
Reboots fix everything?

395
00:19:55.670 --> 00:19:56.770
Imagine this a reboot for

396
00:19:56.770 --> 00:19:59.630
the communication protocol
stack inside of your network.

397
00:19:59.630 --> 00:20:04.200
Kinda like recycling the printer, which is
a fancy term for rebooting the printer.

398
00:20:04.200 --> 00:20:07.020
That's essentially what we're doing
to the protocol stack inside of your

399
00:20:07.020 --> 00:20:07.780
operating system.

400
00:20:07.780 --> 00:20:08.370
>> That's right.
And

401
00:20:08.370 --> 00:20:10.800
once that's done,
you should be back to the races.

402
00:20:10.800 --> 00:20:12.580
And if that was the problem,

403
00:20:12.580 --> 00:20:17.050
if your TCP/IP suite has become messed up,
you do the reset.

404
00:20:17.050 --> 00:20:19.650
Once you've restarted the computer,
you should be back in action.

405
00:20:19.650 --> 00:20:20.970
Everything should start working.

406
00:20:20.970 --> 00:20:25.140
It has definitely saved this guy more
than a time or two, that is for sure.

407
00:20:25.140 --> 00:20:28.360
It's a nice little handy
command to have in the toolkit.

408
00:20:28.360 --> 00:20:30.890
Well Wes,
we've gone through a lot of tools so far.

409
00:20:30.890 --> 00:20:33.180
Is there anything else we wanna
cover before we close the show?

410
00:20:33.180 --> 00:20:36.270
>> You know,
there are plenty of commands out there.

411
00:20:36.270 --> 00:20:38.580
And I remember, guys,
when I first started,

412
00:20:38.580 --> 00:20:42.520

a student and getting certifications.

413
00:20:42.520 --> 00:20:45.590
I remember the first time we opened

414
00:20:45.590 --> 00:20:48.430
Why, why, did I get myself into this and
what have I done?

415
00:20:48.430 --> 00:20:54.190
If this seems a little bit daunting when
you first get into it, don't let it.

416
00:20:54.190 --> 00:20:57.370
It can be, but the moment you start
understanding what you're doing and

417
00:20:57.370 --> 00:21:01.680
practicing some of these commands,
you could become very, very efficient and

418
00:21:01.680 --> 00:21:04.020
you don't need to be tied down to the GUI.

419
00:21:04.020 --> 00:21:06.290
Saying, wel,l they don't make a button for
it, I can't test it.

420
00:21:06.290 --> 00:21:06.948
Well, you know what?

421
00:21:06.948 --> 00:21:07.960
They don't have to make a button,

422
00:21:07.960 --> 00:21:09.730
because you can do it inside
of the command prompt.

423
00:21:09.730 --> 00:21:12.540
So keep it up, practice it, you can do it.

424
00:21:12.540 --> 00:21:15.980
If somebody like me can do it, if somebody
like Dan can do this over the years,

425
00:21:15.980 --> 00:21:18.000
you can do this as well and
just stick to it.

426
00:21:18.000 --> 00:21:20.420
>> Yeah,
one of the things that I took away from

427
00:21:20.420 --> 00:21:24.810
a mentor of mine as I got into IT,
we were learning command lines and

428
00:21:24.810 --> 00:21:26.650
then somebody was like,
why are we learning this?

429
00:21:26.650 --> 00:21:28.070
There's graphics for everything.

430
00:21:28.070 --> 00:21:30.500
There's a GUI for everything, he said.

431
00:21:30.500 --> 00:21:31.960
What happens if you don't have the GUI?

432
00:21:31.960 --> 00:21:32.890
What do you do?

433
00:21:32.890 --> 00:21:36.680
So these command line tools are very
functional, they're very helpful.

434
00:21:36.680 --> 00:21:40.110
Learning them is gonna help you,
you're gonna use them, trust us.

435
00:21:40.110 --> 00:21:42.710
You might use some more than others,
but eventually,

436
00:21:42.710 --> 00:21:46.260
one day, you will probably have
used all of them to some extent.

437
00:21:46.260 --> 00:21:47.940
Wes, thank you so much for stopping by.

438
00:21:47.940 --> 00:21:48.612
>> Absolutely.
>> Thank you for

439
00:21:48.612 --> 00:21:51.040
explaining these cool
tools that we can use.

440
00:21:51.040 --> 00:21:55.650
Definitely developing our tool kit here
for our upcoming network engineers.

441
00:21:55.650 --> 00:21:58.300
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed this
show and learned a little bit, but

442
00:21:58.300 --> 00:21:59.410

443

We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

00:22:01.458 --> 00:22:02.960
I've been your host, Dan Lowrie.

00:22:02.960 --> 00:22:03.770

446
00:22:03.770 --> 00:22:05.756
>> We'll see you next time.

447
00:22:05.756 --> 00:22:13.340

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike demonstrate configuring TCP/IP settings from the command line. They show how to statically map an IP address in a Linux environment using ifconfig and ip, as well as using netsh in a Windows environment.
episodes.title: Setting IP Information
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.060
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.060 --> 00:00:11.368
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.368 --> 00:00:15.826
>> Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV, I'm your host,

4
00:00:15.826 --> 00:00:16.696
Mike Rodrick.

5

And today we're doing command
line networking tools.

6

And specifically this episode,
we're gonna take a look at how

7
00:00:23.379 --> 00:00:28.180

configuration, from the command line.

8
00:00:28.180 --> 00:00:30.670
And here to help us with all

9
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:31.340
How you doing, Daniel?

10
00:00:31.340 --> 00:00:32.530
>> Mike, I couldn't be better.

11
00:00:32.530 --> 00:00:33.760
I'm glad to be on the show today.

12

It's always fun to come
here in the studio and

14
00:00:37.791 --> 00:00:39.347
>> [LAUGH]
>> And today is no exception of that.

15
00:00:39.347 --> 00:00:42.188
We're gonna have a great time today and
like Mike said,

16
00:00:42.188 --> 00:00:45.830
we're going to try to set our IP
information through the command line.

17
00:00:45.830 --> 00:00:49.640
Now, I know, right, normally, we live in
a GUI world, and we all love them, right?

18
00:00:49.640 --> 00:00:50.900
Because they're so easy.

19
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:55.350
I just go into the little graphical box,

if I need to do a static IP,

00:00:59.980 --> 00:01:03.010
I just type in the information,
and I'm off to the races.

23
00:01:03.010 --> 00:01:08.290
But what if I don't have that option, what
if I'm maybe remoted in from somewhere,

24
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:13.110
and I'm only inside of a command line
utility, that's all I gotta work with.

25
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:13.740
But guess what?

26
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:14.540
You're not out in the weeds.

27
00:01:14.540 --> 00:01:18.590
We can still set that IP information, and
that's what we're gonna try to do today.

28
00:01:18.590 --> 00:01:21.790
>> So there are some times, are there
advantages of doing it through the GUI

29
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:26.450
versus using the command line over the
GUI, or is it more of a what I feel like

30
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:29.800
using today, or other times when
that's all I have available?

31
00:01:29.800 --> 00:01:32.400
>> Yeah, that's really what it's
gonna boil down to, a lot of times,

32
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:35.300
it's gonna be just because that's
what you have available to you.

33
00:01:35.300 --> 00:01:38.890
I've logged into a headless server,
and I need to set IP information.

34
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:41.480
We don't have a GUI to rely on.

35
00:01:41.480 --> 00:01:44.750
Other times, we might wanna do some
scripting, that can also come into play.

36
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:47.650
You'll be able to script things
like this out, that's always fun.

37
00:01:47.650 --> 00:01:52.700
But typically, it's because we just don't
have a graphical user interface, or

38
00:01:52.700 --> 00:01:56.460
you just might be old school, and
you want to just stay in one spot.

39
00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:58.850
It's nice to be able to
throw the commands at it.

40
00:01:58.850 --> 00:02:02.420
None of these are too terribly
difficult to remember or lengthy.

41
00:02:02.420 --> 00:02:03.430
A couple of them can be,

42
00:02:03.430 --> 00:02:06.590
but if you have them underneath your belt,
why jump around?

43
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:08.830
I gotta go here, I gotta go there,
it's easier to stay.

44
00:02:08.830 --> 00:02:10.110
I'm in the command line already.

45
00:02:10.110 --> 00:02:11.770
I can go ahead and
set that information from here.

46
00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:13.820
>> That's exactly what I find, Daniel.

47
00:02:13.820 --> 00:02:17.610
I'm definitely a GUI driven guy,
but with Server,

48
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:21.950
where I spend a lot of my time,
we deal with Core, and now Nano.

49
00:02:21.950 --> 00:02:24.620
And so, as you were saying,
headless systems where the only

50
00:02:24.620 --> 00:02:27.950
option is that command prompt, or
PowerShell in the case of Windows.

51
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:31.460
And I tell you, what I've found is
that once you learn those commands,

52
00:02:31.460 --> 00:02:35.060
and once you have them under your belt,
when I go back to a system that has a GUI,

53
00:02:35.060 --> 00:02:38.850
it's actually a little bit faster
if I do it through PowerShell,

54
00:02:38.850 --> 00:02:41.830
especially when the operating systems
change all the time, and, okay,

55
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:45.010
where is this setting, and
where have you hidden it now, Microsoft?

56
00:02:45.010 --> 00:02:48.310
Or, whatever different operating systems,
they all have a terminal,

57
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:50.480
you can get to it,
the commands are the same,

58
00:02:50.480 --> 00:02:52.600
no matter what the flavor of
the desktop you're looking at.

59
00:02:52.600 --> 00:02:54.130
>> Yeah, Mike makes a great point.

60
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:55.520
He's absolutely right.

61
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:58.391
If you're working with something
like a Linux system, right,

62
00:02:58.391 --> 00:02:59.826
Linux systems are notorious for

63
00:02:59.826 --> 00:03:03.193
the graphical environments being
completely different from each other.

64
00:03:03.193 --> 00:03:07.984
Some similarities, but I don't know where
Ubuntu puts the networking configuration

65
00:03:07.984 --> 00:03:10.622
utility, versus where RedHat's putting it.

66
00:03:10.622 --> 00:03:15.697
And if I'm bouncing around RedHat and
Ubuntu, and now I'm on a system.

67
00:03:15.697 --> 00:03:19.090
It's a whole lot easier if well, let me
just jump into the terminal and do this.

68
00:03:19.090 --> 00:03:21.320
Or if Windows decides, hey, you know what?

69
00:03:21.320 --> 00:03:22.450
We're not gonna put that there anymore.

70
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:27.040
I know we've done that for the last 15
years, but welcome to curveball land, and

71
00:03:27.040 --> 00:03:28.840
now you have no idea where to find it.

72
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:32.270
Well, the good news is I can still use
that tried and true command line stuff.

73
00:03:32.270 --> 00:03:34.160
They've been around forever.

74
00:03:34.160 --> 00:03:36.990
Some of them will eventually go away,
and things do change.

75
00:03:36.990 --> 00:03:39.350
We'll see a little bit of that here today.

76
00:03:39.350 --> 00:03:42.650
But for the most part,
they're very venerable,

77
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:45.780
and they're not going where people love
them, they don't wanna see it disappear.

78
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:48.130
So, you can expect them on your systems,

79
00:03:48.130 --> 00:03:50.500
at least as of the shooting
of this episode.

80
00:03:50.500 --> 00:03:51.696
Maybe in the future-
>> [LAUGH]

81
00:03:51.696 --> 00:03:53.282
>> They will be, but as of today,

82
00:03:53.282 --> 00:03:55.179
we get to use these to our advantage.

83
00:03:55.179 --> 00:03:58.434
So, I say we go ahead and hit the ground
running with the first thing.

84
00:03:58.434 --> 00:03:59.810
Let's talk about networking.

85
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:03.311
Right, this is what we're talking about
is command line networking tools, well,

86
00:04:03.311 --> 00:04:05.650
if I can't network,
then I'm not gonna do a whole lot.

87
00:04:05.650 --> 00:04:08.700
All right, what good are the tools if
I can't actually get on the network?

88
00:04:08.700 --> 00:04:13.010
Let's start with setting a static
IP address on different systems.

89
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:16.100
And we'll look at Linux, and
we'll look at Windows as well.

90
00:04:16.100 --> 00:04:19.785
So let's jump into my Linux machine here,
I've already got the command line up.

91
00:04:19.785 --> 00:04:22.170
It is looking a little, there we go,

92
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:26.040
that'd probably be a little easier to
see for you guys, so let's do that.

93
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:29.550
Let's start with the good old ifconfig.

94
00:04:29.550 --> 00:04:33.366
[INAUDIBLE] If you've worked in Windows,
it sounds very similar to the ipconfig,

95
00:04:33.366 --> 00:04:35.094
which we'll look at in a little bit.

96
00:04:35.094 --> 00:04:37.311
But right here inside of Linux,

97
00:04:37.311 --> 00:04:41.262
the good old trusty ifconfig
is what a lot of people know.

98
00:04:41.262 --> 00:04:45.039
And because it's been around for
a long time, it works very well, and

99
00:04:45.039 --> 00:04:47.550
we can set an IP address using IP,
ifconfigs.

100
00:04:47.550 --> 00:04:55.090
So let's do that, the command obviously
is ifconfig, ifconfig, like so.

101
00:04:55.090 --> 00:05:00.570
And if we do a --help, you can see
a lot of different options available,

102
00:05:00.570 --> 00:05:02.490
it's not too bad.

103
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:05.810
If you do the man ifconfig and
look at the menu,

104
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:09.900
it's a little bit more lengthy,
has a lot of options available to it.

105
00:05:09.900 --> 00:05:13.000
It's a very powerful networking tool.

106
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:16.595
So, if you're looking for more advanced
options, they are probably in there.

107
00:05:16.595 --> 00:05:19.880
You just gotta kinda trudge through the
manual and find what you're looking for.

108
00:05:19.880 --> 00:05:24.839
But easy stuff like adding an IP address,
super not difficult at all,

109
00:05:24.839 --> 00:05:26.950
so let's take a look at that.

110
00:05:26.950 --> 00:05:30.170
Let's do ifconfig,
all you have to do to add an IP address.

111
00:05:30.170 --> 00:05:33.220
Ifconfig and then pick your adapter.

112
00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:34.220
Well, what is my adapter?

113
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:38.237
Well, if I just hit ifconfig enter,
I can see that I have two adapters.

114
00:05:38.237 --> 00:05:41.580
I've got this one,
which is eth0, ethernet 0.

115
00:05:41.580 --> 00:05:46.110
Sometimes you'll see en0,
sometimes you'll see Scale.

116
00:05:46.110 --> 00:05:49.160
Maybe you'll think it's a scsi device,
or something like that.

117
00:05:49.160 --> 00:05:50.440
You'll get different names.

118
00:05:50.440 --> 00:05:51.710
That's what you're looking for.

119
00:05:51.710 --> 00:05:54.810
This LO is the loopback adapter.

120
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:58.090
That's just basically the software
version of a network controller, so

121
00:05:58.090 --> 00:05:59.940
you can test the networking stack.

122
00:05:59.940 --> 00:06:02.450
But this is the actual physical address.

123
00:06:02.450 --> 00:06:06.340
And you can see that, because it actually
has, well, it's not showing here, right.

124
00:06:06.340 --> 00:06:07.260
Or is it?

125
00:06:07.260 --> 00:06:09.770
No, it's the IPv6 address.

126
00:06:09.770 --> 00:06:11.945
There's also a Mac address
that goes along with that.

127
00:06:11.945 --> 00:06:13.051
All physical adapters have that.

128
00:06:13.051 --> 00:06:15.722
So, it will be there as well,
we can get that up if we need to.

129
00:06:15.722 --> 00:06:19.879
But that's what I'm looking for
ETH zero, ETH one, ETH two, ENO,

130
00:06:19.879 --> 00:06:23.337
1699732, you'll see all
sorts of crazy names.

131
00:06:23.337 --> 00:06:25.733
And you can do the alias thing and
everything like that.

132
00:06:25.733 --> 00:06:30.318
But right now, that's what I need to know,
that's the information necessary for

133
00:06:30.318 --> 00:06:34.395
us to set the IP address for that adapter,
cuz we're talking specifics.

134
00:06:34.395 --> 00:06:37.385
I can't just say, Ifconfig,
I've got five adapters,

135
00:06:37.385 --> 00:06:39.450
which adapter do you wanna set this to?

136
00:06:39.450 --> 00:06:41.970
>> You have to tell it which one
you're trying to configure with this

137
00:06:41.970 --> 00:06:42.820
particular command.

138
00:06:42.820 --> 00:06:46.240
>> Exactly, so we gotta be a little
specific when it comes to Linux systems,

139
00:06:46.240 --> 00:06:49.720
and we'll find that's even true when
we get into Windows as well, so.

140
00:06:49.720 --> 00:06:51.030
That's one of the big steps.

141
00:06:51.030 --> 00:06:54.110
Always make sure you get the correct
adapter that you're trying to work with.

142
00:06:54.110 --> 00:06:58.530
So now that we know what it is, we can
set that IP address for that adapter.

143
00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:00.065
I've already got an IP address,
and that's fine.

144
00:07:00.065 --> 00:07:01.877
It's a DHCP address.

145
00:07:01.877 --> 00:07:05.306
We'll get into setting DHCP here in
a minute, but I'm gonna change it, and

146
00:07:05.306 --> 00:07:06.900
we're gonna do a static address.

147
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:10.635
So, now I know that it's ETH0,
so we're gonna go ifconfig.

148
00:07:10.635 --> 00:07:16.239
>> And we'll say eth0, and
then we just set what IP address we want.

149
00:07:16.239 --> 00:07:20.473
Right, so, if I wanted to change this to,

150
00:07:20.473 --> 00:07:24.728
we'll say we'll make it 200, right?

151
00:07:24.728 --> 00:07:27.387
So, 192.168.43.200.

152
00:07:27.387 --> 00:07:30.894
Just like that, hit Return
>> No crazy errors, no nothing,

153
00:07:30.894 --> 00:07:33.983
it just goes through, so that lends me
to believe that everything went fine.

154
00:07:33.983 --> 00:07:41.438
If I do ifconfig again, you'll notice
that now my address is set to 200.

155
00:07:41.438 --> 00:07:44.591
>> Now, Daniel, I know,
from my networking days,

156
00:07:44.591 --> 00:07:46.930
we need more than just an IP address.

157
00:07:46.930 --> 00:07:49.940
So, when you set that, you didn't
give it any additional information.

158
00:07:49.940 --> 00:07:52.847
What happened to the other
parameters that we wanna set?

159
00:07:52.847 --> 00:07:55.041
>> Great question, and
Mike is absolutely right.

160
00:07:55.041 --> 00:07:57.317
Sometimes you're gonna have
to set more information.

161
00:07:57.317 --> 00:07:58.454
What I've done here.

162
00:07:58.454 --> 00:08:00.820
This week I said here's an IP address and

163
00:08:00.820 --> 00:08:04.023
the system knows to say well
we've got the classes, so

164
00:08:04.023 --> 00:08:07.612
I'm just gonna give it a standard or-
>> Does it look at that and say okay,

165
00:08:07.612 --> 00:08:10.839
that was a class C address in the old days
so I'm gonna use the class C subnet mask?

166
00:08:10.839 --> 00:08:16.277
>> Exactly, that's exactly right, CIDR
notation is very prevalent through here.

167
00:08:16.277 --> 00:08:19.043
And you can use that as well,

episodes.description: In this episode, Dan and Mike continue their demonstration on configuring TCP/IP settings from the command line. They show how to configure a Linux and a Windows node as a DHCP client. They also look at ways to release and renew a DHCP lease in both operating systems.
